clean_content:
Definition / general

* Mixed epithelial and mesenchymal tumor-like malformation (hamartoma) composed of dental hard and soft tissues

Essential features

* Subdivided into **compound odontoma** and **complex odontoma*** The most common odontogenic tumor* Can obstruct the path of erupting teeth* Most recent WHO Classification of Head and Neck Tumours regards majority of ameloblastic fibro-odontomas as developing odontomas rather than a distinct tumor ([IARC: WHO Classification of Head and Neck Tumours, 4th Edition, 2017](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283224388/pathologyoutl-20))

Terminology

* Compound odontoma* Complex odontoma* Ameloblastic fibro-odontoma* Peripheral odontoma

ICD coding

* ICD-O:
  + [9280/0](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=88) - odontoma+ [9281/0](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=88) - compound odontoma+ [9282/0](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=88) - complex odontoma+ [9290/0](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=88) - ameloblastic fibro-odontoma* ICD-10:
    + [D16.4](http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.4) - benign neoplasm of bones of skull and face+ [D16.5](http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.5) - benign neoplasm of lower jaw bone

Epidemiology

* Most common odontogenic tumor* Usually diagnosed during the first two decades of life* No sex predilection

Sites

* Can occur in any tooth bearing area* Compound odontoma usually occurs in anterior maxilla* Complex odontoma usually occurs in posterior mandible

Pathophysiology

* Unknown; trauma, local infection, inheritance have been proposed

Etiology

* Unknown

Clinical features

* Many asymptomatic; discovered upon exploring potential causes of
  + Asymmetric tooth eruption+ Malposition of erupted teeth+ Occasional devitalization of adjacent teeth* Can become symptomatic due to local infection (sinusitis, infected adjacent tooth, exposure of odontoma to oral environment, etc) and can present with swelling and pain* Size: ranges from several millimeters to 6 cm, most between 1 - 2 cm* Syndrome associations:
        + Gardner syndrome (familial colorectal polyposis): multiple odontoma or supernumerary teeth+ Otodental syndrome* Peripheral odontoma may present as a firm submucosal nodule, most commonly in the maxilla

Diagnosis

* Dependent on clinical, radiologic and pathologic correlation

Radiology description

* Frequently associated with an unerupted tooth* Usually detected on routine radiographs
    + Most commonly located between roots of erupted teeth or impeding the eruption of tooth* Well marginated from surrounding bone
      + May have a thin radiolucent region surrounding opaque mass+ Radiopaque matrix same density as components of adjacent teeth+ Early stage odontoma may have little calcified matrix, expanding the radiographic differential diagnosis* Can occur as a component of combined odontogenic tumor, most commonly [Calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor (CCOT)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html)* Multiple odontomas may occur as a component of:
          + Gardner syndrome (familial colorectal polyposis)+ Otodental syndrome* Multiple supernumerary teeth (similar radiographic appearance) can occur as a component of cleidocranial dysostosis or arise in non syndromic setting

Radiology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5543623/figure/F2/)

Lesion in left side of the mandible

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih02.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5545622/figure/f1-11mjms24032017_cr1/)

Compound odontoma and unerupted 32

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih03.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5192025/figure/F1/ )

Well defined multiple radiopacities

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih04.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5072101/figure/F2/)

Radio opaque lesion surrounded by radiolucent zone

Prognostic factors

* Recurrence uncommon for isolated sporadic odontoma* Remaining teeth in region of odontoma may be affected by the presence of odontoma and require treatment

Case reports

* 4 year old girl with bilateral amorphic radio-opaque masses in the body of the mandible ([J Craniofac Surg 2009;20:973](19461348))* 7 year old boy with left mandibular body mass ([Imaging Sci Dent 2016;46:267](28035305))* 11 year old girl with painless nodular lesion on the palatal gingiva close to the incisive papilla ([Autops Case Rep 2018;8:e2018009](29515984))* 12 year old boy with painful swelling of the left cheek ([Rom J Morphol Embryol 2013;54:1153](24399016))

Treatment

* Peripheral odontomas usually treated by excision* Central (intraosseous) complex and compound odontomas usually treated by enucleation and curettage* Remaining teeth in region of odontoma may be affected, requiring treatment

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih05.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5828291/figure/g01/)

Peripheral odontoma

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih06.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5545622/figure/f2-11mjms24032017_cr1/)

Surgical site showing denticles

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih07.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5072101/figure/F1/)

Mass in upper left maxillary region​​

Gross images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaodontoma_nih08.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5545622/figure/f3-11mjms24032017_cr1/)

Enucleated nine denticles

Microscopic (histologic) description

* **General**:
  + Can have scant or occasional ghost cell formation, can cause confusion with COC (CCOT / Gorlin cyst) [Calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor (CCOT)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html)
    - Odontoma can also occur as a component of COC (about 20% of COC associated with odontoma)+ Odontoma is composed of dental hard tissues; dentin and enamel
      - Bone is not a dental hard tissue  
  * **Compound**:
    + Histologically similar to the layering of normal tooth in the relation of dentin, enamel matrix and pulp  
    * **Complex**:
      + More disorganized or haphazard arrangement of pulpal tissues, enamel or dentin

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Kelly Magliocca, D.D.S., M.P.H.  

[![Odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillawhoMagliocca14.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillawhoMagliocca14.jpg)

Odontoma

[![Compound odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca06new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca06new.jpg)
 
[![Compound odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca07new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca07new.jpg)
 
[![Compound odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca08new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca08new.jpg)

Compound odontoma

  

[![Complex odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca01new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca01new.jpg)
 
[![Complex odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca02new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca02new.jpg)
 
[![Complex odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca03new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca03new.jpg)
 
[![Complex odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca05new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaodontomamagliocca05new.jpg)

Complex odontoma

Differential diagnosis

* **Complex**:
  + Malformed tooth developing in area of prior trauma
    - Could be histologically identical to complex odontoma+ [Osteoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaosteoma.html)
      - Benign neoplasm composed of mature lamellar bone (compact, trabecular or both)- Can also affect craniofacial bones- Should not have odontogenic epithelium+ [Ameloblastic fibro-odontoma (AFO)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaodontoma.html)
        - Has biphasic (mesenchymal and odontogenic epithelium) "soft tissue" component that is identical to ameloblastic fibroma- Also contains a calcifying component composed of enamel and dentin structures- Most recent WHO Classification of Head and Neck Tumours regards most cases of AFO as developing odontomas rather than a distinct tumor ([IARC: WHO Classification of Head and Neck Tumours, 4th Edition, 2017](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283224388/pathologyoutl-20))  
  * **Compound**:
    + Supernumerary teeth
      - Complete well formed teeth- Usually in males- Can rarely be associated with syndromes such as cleidocranial dysostosis  
    * **General**:
      + [Calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor (CCOT)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html)
        - Benign cystic tumor of odontogenic origin, current terminology favors use of calcifying odontogenic cyst rather than CCOT ([IARC: WHO Classification of Head and Neck Tumours, 4th Edition, 2017](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283224388/pathologyoutl-20))- Can have ameloblastic epithelium: columnar or cuboidal basal cells with lumen lined by tissue resembling stellate reticulum- Will have ghost cells or anucleate epithelial cells- Can also have dentinoid material admixed with odontogenic epithelial rests- Separate discrete focus of odontoma may be present in approximately 20% of cases

Additional references

* [Orphanet J Rare Dis 2006;1:5](16722606)
